PHYSICAL JOURNAL E

Bidisperse granular avalanches on inclined planes: A rich variety
of behaviors
C. Goujona, B. Dalloz-Dubrujeaud, and N. Thomas
IUSTI, Universit´e de Provence, CNRS UMR 6595, 5 rue Enrico Fermi, 13453 Marseille cedex 13, France

Received 13 October 2006 and Received in ﬁnal form 4 April 2007
Published online: 5 July 2007 – c⃝EDP Sciences / Societ`a Italiana di Fisica / Springer-Verlag 2007

Abstract. Experiments were performed to provide insight into the ﬂow behavior and structure of bimodal
mixtures of grains in gravity-driven, free-surface ﬂows. Unsteady unconﬁned ﬂows were produced by re-
leasing instantaneously a dry granular mass, composed of two particle sizes, over a rough inclined plane.
As a result of size segregation, the small particles are found at the bottom of the ﬂow and ﬁnal deposit,
the large particles are found at the free surface, but also on the lateral borders and at the front of the
ﬂow. The lateral and vertical inhomogeneous repartitions of particles lead to two main eﬀects that are
completely absent in monodispersed ﬂows. The outline eﬀect results from the accumulation of large beads
on the periphery of the ﬂow depending on the value of the relative friction of each particle species on the
plane. This eﬀect in turn causes a narrowing of the ﬂow and/or an increase of length of the ﬁnal deposit.
The interface eﬀect results of the interaction between layers of diﬀerent size particles and causes the mod-
iﬁcation of the thickness of the deposit. These eﬀects occur simultaneously and their combination leads to
a great variety of behaviors. In this investigation, evidence of the diversity of behaviors is presented as the
size ratio, relative friction and concentration of each particle species are varied.
PACS. 45.70.Mg Granular ﬂow: mixing, segregation and stratiﬁcation – 45.70.Ht Avalanches

The ﬂow of dense granular matter on inclined planes is
often encountered in engineering applications involving
the transport of materials such as minerals and cereals.
It is also common in geophysical situations where rock
avalanches, landslides and pyroclastic and debris ﬂows are
natural events consisting in large-scale ﬂows of particles [1,
2]. Many studies concerning monodisperse dry granular
ﬂows on inclined rough planes are available in the litera-
ture. However, most of these studies were made with ﬂow-
ing beads of the same size [3] or sometimes greater [4]
than the beads glued on the plane. But most industrial
or natural ﬂows do not propagate on a roughness com-
posed of the same size of particles than the ﬂow. A sys-
tematic investigation has shown the importance of the rel-
ative roughness on the basal friction [5]. Moreover, the
natural ﬂows are often polydisperse in size. For example,
geophysical events involve complex heterogeneous granu-
lar material made of particles of various sizes ranging from
micrometers to meters, and sometimes mixed with ﬂuids.
One question in Earth Sciences, for which we give possible
clues in this paper, is the surprising long travel of these

04510, M´exico; e-mail: celine.goujon@gmail.com

ﬂows. In such polydispersed material, it is well known that
segregation occurs and that the large particles rise up to
the free surface. There are a number of mechanisms for
the segregation of dissimilar grains in granular ﬂows [6],
including inter-particle percolation, convection [7], inertia,
collisional condensation [8], diﬀerential air drag, cluster-
ing [9] and kinetic sieving [10–16], which is the dominant
mechanism in dense granular free-surface ﬂows. Moreover,
due to their position in the velocity gradient, the veloc-
ity of the large beads is greater than the velocity of small
beads. This diﬀerence of velocity implies that the large
beads go forth to the front [17–19] and are on the sides of
the ﬂow (this is a consequence of the lateral spreading of
the front [18]). This repartition of large beads can modify
the propagation of the avalanche [20]. One consequence of
this accumulation of large beads at the ﬂow front is the
ﬁngering behavior which is observed for natural ﬂows but
also in laboratory experiments [21,22]. Whatever the poly-
dispersity of a granular ﬂow, the segregation is systematic
and modiﬁes the dynamics of the granular ﬂow.

In this paper, we study several bidisperse ﬂows induced
by the release of granular matter contained under a cap
(Fig. 1). We vary the diameter of each class of beads pre-
sent in the mixture, the size of the beads glued on the
plane being constant. Due to the phenomenon of segre-
gation, lateral and vertical inhomogeneous repartitions of

Fig. 1. Experimental device for bidisperse granular ﬂows on an
inclined rough plane: (a) the volume of beads is placed under
a cap on the plane; (b) the cap is removed, the released mate-
rial ﬂows down the slope; (c) the ﬂow stops leaving a deposit
characterized by its length L, its width W and its thickness
hstop. The plane is made rough by gluing beads on it.

beads occur. We have identiﬁed diﬀerent interactions: the
interaction of the small beads with the rough plane at the
bottom of the ﬂow, the interaction of large beads with the
rough plane at the periphery of the ﬂow and the inter-
action between the layers of small and large beads. The
combination of these interactions can lead to diﬀerent be-
haviors for bidisperse ﬂows. These behaviors allow one to
highlight the mechanisms governing these ﬂows.
In Section 2, we brieﬂy report previous results con-
cerning monodisperse ﬂows since they will be used to in-
terpret the present results. The experimental device, the
measurement methods and the bidisperse mixtures are de-
scribed in Section 3. In Section 4, we present several ﬂow
behaviors. Each type of ﬂow is studied by presenting a de-
scription of the deposit, the dynamics of the ﬂow and the
evolution of the ﬂow and of the deposit with the propor-
tion of large beads. Moreover, we present the evolution of
the deposit with the diameter of each class of beads. In re-
lation with these observations, an interpretation implying
two eﬀects and their combination is given in Section 5.

2 Previous results: basal friction and ﬂow
dynamics

In this part, we present previous results concerning mono-
disperse granular ﬂows on inclined rough planes. We pre-
sent successively 1) the behavior of a layer of grains on an
inclined plane, 2) for each rough plane, the existence of a
diameter of ﬂowing beads dc for which the basal friction
is maximum and, 3) the rheological laws for these ﬂows.
Moreover, we present a theoretical determination of the
diameter dc.
An initially static granular layer of uniform thickness
h starts ﬂowing when the inclination of the plane is above
a critical angle θstart. Once initiated, the ﬂow is sustained
until the inclination is decreased down to a second crit-
ical angle θstop. The existence of these two angles is the
evidence of the hysteretic nature of granular ﬂows. In the
case of inclined planes, these critical angles depend on the
layer thickness h [23]. Reciprocally, these thresholds can
be interpreted in terms of the critical layer thicknesses

Fig. 2. Phase diagram (h, θ) for granular ﬂows on inclined
rough planes: for θ < θ1, no stationary ﬂow is possible, for
θ1 < θ, stationary ﬂow exists, for θ > θ2, no beads stay on the
plane after the ﬂow passed (hstop = 0).

hstop(θ) and hstart(θ). Indeed, the measurement of hstop
is easier than θstop as it corresponds to the thickness of
the deposit remaining on the plane once the ﬂow stops [3,
24,25]. The two curves hstop(θ) and hstart(θ) divide the
phase diagram (h, θ) in three regions (Fig. 2): a region
where uniform ﬂow is not possible (h < hstop), a subcrit-
ical region where both static and ﬂowing layer can exist
(hstop < h < hstart) and a region where ﬂow always oc-
curs h > hstart. The curves hstop(θ) and hstart(θ) exhibit
the same shape for all the materials and the curve hstop(θ)
can be ﬁtted by

where d is the diameter of the ﬂowing beads and the pa-
rameters θ1, θ2 and B depend on both the bulk material
and the roughness conditions of the plane [3,5,18,23,24,
26,27]. θ1 is deﬁned by the fact that for every angle of
inclination smaller than θ1 no uniform steady ﬂow can be
observed. θ2 is the angle of inclination of the plane for
which no beads stay static on the plane.
For monodisperse dry granular ﬂows on inclined
planes, there is a diameter of beads dc for which the basal
friction of the ﬂow is maximum [5]. The value of dc is
diﬀerent for each plane and depends on the geometrical
characteristics of the roughness of the plane (bump size λ
and compactness C). This maximum of the basal friction
is linked to a minimum of the mean velocity of the sta-
tionary ﬂow, a maximum of the deposit thickness and a
minimum of the deposit length. This maximum of basal
friction at dc is also linked to a maximum of the angle θ2.
A simple model of stability of one bead on the plane gives
the value of θ2 and the value of dc as a function of the
characteristics of the plane [5]:

C. Goujon et al.: Bidisperse granular avalanches on inclined planes: A rich variety of behaviors
201

Fig. 3. Coeﬃcient of friction µ as a function of the inertial
parameter I, for I = 0, µ = tan θ1, for I →∞, µ →tan θ2.

The appropriate ﬂow law to describe dissipation in dry
granular ﬂows is still under debate. However, it is possi-
ble to distinguish two approaches. The ﬁrst approach pro-
posed by [28] is based on the fact that the components of
the stress tensor are deduced from the Coulomb plastic-
ity criterion, in this case, the resulting ﬂow law takes into
account the anisotropy of normal stresses [29,30].
The second approach uses a parameterization of the
friction coeﬃcient µ = tan θ as a function of the avalanche
mean velocity and the thickness. This law is obtained
from experiments on steady uniform ﬂows over inclined
planes [3,31]. This model indicates that the friction force
exactly balances the force of gravity. In the case of gran-
ular media, experimental data and Coulomb theory show
that bed-parallel stresses in quasi-static granular media
are not simply due to hydrostatic pressure. However, this
model is able to describe the experimental observation of
steady uniform ﬂows over a plane for a given range of in-
clination angles contrary to Savage-Hutter’s type models.
It has been also tested for non-uniform experimental [25]
and numerical [32] ﬂows. Even if we use the results of the
second approach to interpret our results, the aim of this
paper is not to diﬀerentiate between the two approaches.
A local rheology linking the stresses (normal stress P
and shear stress τ) and the shear rate ˙γ for the case of
granular ﬂows down an inclined plane was proposed [23,
33,34]:
τ/P = µ(I)
with P = ρg(h −z) cos θ; τ/P = tan θ and

where µ corresponds to the coeﬃcient of friction, I is an
inertial parameter, ρ is the ﬂow mass density, g is the grav-
ity, h is the thickness of the ﬂow, z the direction perpen-
dicular to the plane oriented upward (z = 0 corresponds
to the bottom of the granular ﬂow), θ the inclination of
the plane, d is the diameter of the ﬂowing beads, ˙γ is the
shear rate.
The inertial parameter I tends to 0 when the thickness
of the deposit hstop tends to inﬁnity which corresponds

Fig. 4. Coeﬃcient of friction µ increases with the inertial
parameter I, for diﬀerent diameters of ﬂowing beads: ◦d =
132 µm, □d = 225 µm, • d = 275 µm, × d = 325 µm,
+ d = 450 µm. The coeﬃcient of friction is maximum for
d = dc = 275 µm (λ = 425 µm).

to the case where the angle of inclination of the plane
tends to θ1. Respectively, the inertial parameter tends to
inﬁnity when the angle of inclination of the plane tends to
θ2 (hstop = 0). The curve which represents the variation
of the coeﬃcient of friction µ with the inertial parameter
tends to µ2 = tan θ2 for large values of I. A representative
curve of µ(I) is presented on Figure 3.
Using this local rheology for z = 0, the friction coef-
ﬁcient becomes the basal friction of the ﬂow. It has been
shown [35], for experiments of uniform stationary ﬂows
on a rough plane (λ = 425 µm, d = 135; 225; 275; 325;
450 µm), that the evolution of this basal friction versus
the inertial parameter is compatible with Figure 3. For
d = dc = 275 µm, the evolution µ(I) is always higher that
for the other value of d, and the µ(I) curves do not cross
(Fig. 4). The knowledge of the upper limit of the coeﬃcient
of friction at large values of I (µ2) allows one to determine
the sorting of the curves µ(I). In other words, for large
(indexed l) and small (indexed s) beads, if µ2,s > µ2,l (re-
spectively, µ2,s < µ2,l), whatever the value of the inertial
parameter I, µs(I) > µl(I) (respectively, µs(I) < µl(I)):
the basal friction of large beads on the rough plane is al-
ways smaller (respectively, greater) than the basal friction
of the small beads on the rough plane. Using a model [5],
it is possible to calculate θ2 and then µ2 for each diameter
of ﬂowing bead on a given plane: µ2 is constant for small
diameters then increases, presents a maximum for dc of
the plane and decreases to zero for greater diameters (see
Fig. 5 for a typical shape of µ2(d)).
In the present study, experiments are done with a mix-
ture of large and small beads. Using Figure 5, it is pos-
sible to determine µ2 for large and small beads (dl, ds)
and compare them to know which one is the larger one.
We see that if ds (abscissa of the black dot in Fig. 5) is

Fig. 5. Coeﬃcient of friction µ2 (µ2 = limI→∞µ(I)) as a
function of the diameter d of the ﬂowing beads on a given
plane. This curve is obtained from [35]. dc is characteristic of
the plane. The point (•) represents the chosen value of the
diameter ds. The hatched area corresponds to the diameters of
large beads giving the following conﬁgurations for the mixture:
(a) µ2,s < µ2,l, (b) µ2,s > µ2,l, (c) if ds > dc, µ2,s > µ2,l,
whatever the diameter of large beads.

inferior to dc, there is a range of dl values (hatched area
in Fig. 5) where µ2,l is larger than µ2,s (Fig. 5(a)) and
a range where it is smaller (Fig. 5(b)). If ds > dc, then
µ2,l is always superior to µ2,s (Fig. 5(c)). The mixtures
used here are then classiﬁed in three diﬀerent categories
(Fig. 5):

– ds < dc:
– Group A: µ2,s < µ2,l, the diameter of large beads
is chosen such that the basal friction of small beads
is smaller than the basal friction of large beads on
the rough plane (Fig. 5(a)).
– Group B: µ2,s > µ2,l, the diameter of large beads
is chosen such that the basal friction of small beads
is larger than the basal friction of small beads on
the rough plane (Fig. 5(b)).
– Group C: ds > dc, in this case, the basal friction of
the large beads µ2,l is always smaller than the basal
friction of the small beads µ2,s : µ2,s > µ2,l (Fig. 5(c))

The behavior of these three conﬁgurations is studied in
this paper.

The experimental device consists in a 1.5 m long and 60 cm
wide rough plane whose inclination (θ) can be controlled
precisely (0.1◦of uncertainty). The particles are glass

beads. We sieve the beads to obtain diﬀerent ranges be-
tween 300 µm and 3 mm. Each range of beads is considered
as monodisperse as the width of the distribution is less
than 10% of the mean diameter of each class (controlled
by image analysis). These beads are used for ﬂows and for
the rough plane. The plane is made rough by gluing one
layer of beads on it (the diameter of these beads is equal
to λ = 1.4 mm in this paper, the compactness C of the
plane is measured and it is equal to 0.56). The control pa-
rameters of this study are the roughness of the plane, the
angle of inclination, the volume of the mixture, but also
the diﬀerent sizes of beads present in the mixture, and the
concentration of large beads in the mixture. The variation
of all these parameters will lead to a huge number of ex-
periments, that is why, only the inﬂuence of the diameter
ratio and the percentage of large beads in the bidisperse
mixture are studied.
On this plane, the experiments consist in the instan-
taneous release of a ﬁxed volume of beads placed on the
plane (see details on the experiments on [5]). The volume
is placed under a hemispherical cap (9.3 cm in diameter),
which is instantaneously removed (Fig. 1(a)). The released
material ﬂows down the slope, spreads both longitudinally
and laterally (Fig. 1(b)) and ultimately stops leaving a de-
posit characterized by its length L, its width W and its
thickness hstop (Fig. 1(c)). The mass of beads and the
slope are dominant parameters, we keep them constant to
study the eﬀect of the bidispersity on the ﬂow: the angle of
the slope is for the two ﬁrst groups of experiments (group
A and B) equal to 25◦, for the third group of experiments
(group C), the angle of the slope is equal to 19◦. The mass
of beads poured into the cap is weighted before each run
and is equal to 176 g. We deﬁne %l as the percentage of
large beads present in the mixture.

The thickness of the deposit is measured by the deviation
of the projection of a laser sheet. Two diﬀerent pictures
are compared: the ﬁrst one is obtained with no beads on
the plane; the second one with the deposit. The devia-
tion of the laser sheet is proportional to the thickness of
the deposit (hstop). The scale is determined by the devia-
tion given by a plate whose thickness is known. With this
method, thickness is measured with 100 µm of uncertainty.
Another
method,
developed
by
Pouliquen
and
Forterre [25] inspired by a Moir´e method [36] is used.
A grid pattern made of horizontal black and white lines
is projected on the plane by an overhead projector. The
projection angle is chosen such that the presence of the
granular mass on the surface induces a signiﬁcant defor-
mation of the grid. Pictures of the plane are recorded by a
camera positioned perpendicularly to the plane. The local
shift of the lines from the initial regular pattern (when the
surface is free of beads) to the deformed pattern (in the
presence of a granular mass) is proportional to the local
thickness of the granular layer. This method is used in the
case where the thickness is not uniform along the deposit.
The thickness is measured with 200 µm of error.

C. Goujon et al.: Bidisperse granular avalanches on inclined planes: A rich variety of behaviors
203

Fig. 6. Length L and thickness hstop of the deposit for mono-
disperse ﬂows for two angles of inclination θ: θ = 25◦(•);
θ = 27◦(□): The coeﬃcient of friction µ2 is maximum for
d = dc = 755 µm. (L = 200 cm arbitrary means that no beads
stay on the plane.)

The measurements of the velocity are obtained with
spatio-temporal diagrams. A calibration relating the
lengths (in cm) with the pixels of the image allows a pre-
cise measurement of the velocity in the case of uniform
steady ﬂows. Errors on the velocities are about 3 mm/s.
In the case of unsteady ﬂows, the spatio-temporal diagram
allows one to determine the variation of the velocity with
time.
The rough plane is black and the deposit of the beads
is white or light gray. The variation of the gray values,
determined on lines perpendicular to the direction of the
ﬂow, allows one to determine the width of the deposit
with a precision equal to 1.4 mm. The same results can
be obtained from the measurements made by the Moir´e
method (the error on the width is also equal to 1.4 mm).
The measurements of the lengths of the deposit are
made directly with a tape measure, the precision is esti-
mated to be 2 mm.

We ﬁrst study monodisperse ﬂows [5]. For each size of
beads, the cap is ﬁlled, placed on the plane and removed.

Table 1. Diﬀerent groups of experiments performed in this
study. These groups are deﬁned by conditions on the diameter
of the beads and on the relative friction on each class of beads
on the plane.

Table 2. Diameter (µm) of small and large beads used for the
diﬀerent experiments performed in this study. The diﬀerent
groups A, B, C are delineated.

Thickness and length of the deposit are measured. The
study of these monodisperse ﬂows on the plane we use
in this paper, allows one to determine the diameter dc
for which the basal friction is maximum. We found dc =
755 µm (Fig. 6).
For the diﬀerent cases shown in Figure 5, we used
beads of the following sizes:

The conditions for each group and the beads used for the
diﬀerent experiments of each group are presented in Ta-
bles 1, 2.
The homogeneity of the initial mixture could be an im-
portant parameter. However, because of the segregation,
it is diﬃcult to make a homogeneous mixture in the cap.
Two methods are used to obtain homogeneous mixtures:
the ﬁrst consists to lightly “stir” the mixture of beads. The
homogeneity of the mixture is visible because of the dif-
ferent colors of the beads. The second method consists to
ﬁll the hemisphere with several alternate layers of each
class of beads. The thickness of each layer is equal to

1.5 mm which represents approximately 1 to 4 diameters
of beads, depending on the beads size: in the hemisphere,
there are approximately ﬁfteen layers. The ﬁrst type of
mixture is less homogeneous than the second one. We test
the two methods in each regime; for regimes presented in
Sections 4.2.2 and 4.2.3, no diﬀerence was observed and
the stirring method is used for simplicity. For the con-
ﬁning regime (Sect. 4.2.1), and the formation of a ﬁn-
ger, diﬀerences were observed. The stirring method gives
non-reproducible results for conditions at the limit of the
ﬁnger formation. Moreover, some asymmetric ﬁnger may
form sometimes probably due to lateral inhomogeneity in
the cap. These two facts disappear when using the lay-
ered method, which gives reproducible results and almost
symmetrical ﬁngers. For that reason, experiments in the
conﬁning regime were done with layered initial mixtures.
For all the experiments, the measurable characteristics
of the ﬂows are

– the velocity of the downstream front,
– the velocity of the rear front composed of large beads,
which appears during the stopping phase of the ﬂow.
The characteristics of the deposit are

– the length of the deposit L,
– the longitudinal evolution of the width W(x),
– the thickness of the deposit hstop.

The segregation due to the diameter diﬀerence between
each class of beads is a very fast phenomenon (the time
to separate the two classes is smaller than 0.5 seconds in
all the experiments). In the following, we suppose that the
segregation is total, which means that the diﬀerent classes
of beads are totally separated during the ﬂow. We also as-
sume that the two classes of beads are separated all along
the ﬂow. With these assumptions, it is possible to simplify
bidisperse ﬂows (Fig. 7(a)) in two regions ﬂowing together:

– a layer where there is only small beads,
– a layer where there is only large beads.

The experimental observations of bidisperse ﬂows allow
one to suppose that these assumptions are valid. For
all the experiments we perform, the inverse segregation
(large beads at the base of the ﬂow) is never observed,
which is surprising because it is observed in channel ﬂow
for size ratios above 5 [37]. This is probably due to the
small thickness of the unconﬁned ﬂow in our study.
During the ﬂow, the large beads are at the top of the
ﬂow, they accumulate at the front, and because of the
spreading of the front, the large beads appear also on the
sides (Fig. 7(b)) which are static during the ﬂow [18].
In order to determine the modiﬁcations of the mor-
phology of a bidisperse deposit, it is necessary to deﬁne
a reference state. Reference states could be monodisperse
granular ﬂows of beads with a diameter ds or dl. However,

Fig. 7. Representation of bidisperse ﬂows on rough inclined
planes, assuming that the segregation is total and instanta-
neous. (a) There are two layers: a layer composed of small
beads at the base of the ﬂow and a layer composed of large
beads at the free surface of the ﬂow. (b) The large beads are
at the periphery (on the sides and at the front) and at the
surface of the ﬂow.

Fig. 8. Reference states for bidisperse ﬂows: (a) reference state
1: the two classes of beads deposit successively onto the plane;
(b) reference state 2: the two classes of beads stay superposed
when they deposit.

it appears in our experiments that one important parame-
ter is the percentage of large beads present in the mixture.
The reference state that we choose, is a mixed state. This
reference state is based on the assumption that the seg-
regation is total and that there is no interaction between
the small and large beads, which modiﬁes the deposit of
small and large beads (this last point is not true in the real
bidisperse ﬂow). This assumption leads to determine the
length of the deposit knowing the lengths of monodisperse
deposit of each class on this plane. Two cases may occur:

– The two classes of beads deposit successively onto the
plane (Fig. 8(a)). In this case, we suppose that the

and large beads.

deposit (Fig. 8(b)) or no large beads stay on the plane.
In this case, we suppose that the height of small beads
is equal to hstop,s and the height of large beads on small
beads layer does not matter. The reference state is the
deposit left by a monodisperse ﬂow of small beads with
diﬀerent mass of beads, that means diﬀerent percent-
age of ﬁlling of the cap.

On the other hand, due to the fact that the maximal
width does not depend on the diameter of ﬂowing beads
for monodisperse ﬂows [5], we suppose that the maximal
width of the deposit is equal to the maximal width of a
monodisperse ﬂow. The reference state length Lref,1 for
the longitudinally separated deposits is then equal to

and the reference state length Lref,2 for the layered de-
posits is

– Ls (respectively, Ll): the length of the deposit left by
a monodisperse ﬂow of a full cap of small beads (re-
spectively, large beads),
– %l: the percentage of large beads present in the mix-
ture.

Supposing that the segregation is total and instanta-
neous, the bidisperse ﬂows are governed by the following
interactions (Fig. 7):

– interaction of small beads with the rough plane,
– interaction of small and large beads layers,
– interaction of large beads with the rough plane.

Depending on the geometry, these interactions give diﬀer-
ent eﬀects.
The ﬁrst one is an “outline eﬀect”: the large beads,
which are at the periphery of the ﬂow (on the sides and at
the front), have an inﬂuence on the shape of the deposit
left by a bidisperse granular ﬂow.
The second one are “interface eﬀects”. These eﬀects
consist in the interaction of small beads with the rough
plane, and in the interaction of large beads with under-
lying moving small beads. These eﬀects have an inﬂuence
on the total thickness of the deposit.

During the bidisperse ﬂows, these eﬀects are all present
with varying importance depending on the characteristic
of the mixture. Their combination leads to a great variety
of behaviors. For understanding the modiﬁcation of the
ﬂow by these eﬀects, we consider the diﬀerent conﬁgura-
tions of mixture (groups A, B and C) which have been
presented before. They take into account:

– The value of the diameter of small beads ds compared
to dc. That determines the basal roughness of the ﬂow,
due to the position of the small beads at the base of

The three diﬀerent behaviors of the bidisperse ﬂows de-
pend on the diameters of each class of beads compared to
dc which determine their relative frictions on the plane. In
this section, we present two mechanisms with which the
great diversity of the behaviors of bidisperse ﬂows (shape
of the deposit, superposed or not layers of beads, variation
of the thickness) can be explained:

– an outline eﬀect due to a large or small basal friction
of large beads at the periphery of the ﬂow,
– interface eﬀects due to the interaction of small beads
with the rough plane and to the interaction of small
beads with large beads at the interface between the
two layers of beads.
5.1 Outline eﬀect of large beads on the ﬂow

The outline eﬀect takes into account the interactions of
large beads with the rough plane at the periphery of

the ﬂow. This eﬀect can be interpreted through the µ(I)
curves of small and large beads on the plane.

– If µ2,s < µ2,l, the large beads, being at the periphery
of the ﬂow, slow down and narrow the ﬂow. The de-
crease of the width of the deposit is then faster than in
the monodisperse case. One explanation of this mech-
anism, called in the following “conﬁning”, could be
schematically represented as shown in Figure 24. The
large beads create a slow moving barrier at the front
of the ﬂow. This barrier slows down the ﬂow, and also
slows down the spreading of the front, preventing the
ﬂow to establish with the width that it would have
in the monodisperse case. The ﬂow is narrowed. Due
to the ﬂow, this barrier may break or not. If the bar-
rier does not break, the ﬂow will stop (Fig. 24(a)).
If the barrier breaks, the width of the ﬂow decreases
and the deposit is composed of one or several ﬁngers
(Fig. 24(b)). The decrease of the width of the ﬂow (and
of the deposit) leads to an increase of the total length
of the deposit due to the use of a ﬁxed volume of beads
in the cap. With this mechanism, it can be explained
that there is a range of percentages of large beads for
which the ﬁngering is possible: there needs to be large
enough beads to conﬁne the ﬂow and not too many be-
cause they would stop the ﬂow. This is why we observe
ﬁngering for 30 < %l < 70.
– If µ2,s > µ2,l, the basal friction of the large beads is
smaller than the basal friction of the small beads. The
large beads, which are at the periphery of the ﬂow,
have no inﬂuence on the morphology of the deposit
(Fig. 19).

The conﬁning can be seen on the proﬁles of the width
of deposits left by bidisperse ﬂows (Fig. 25). In the in-
creasing part, the proﬁle of the width is the same in all
the experiments. The maximum value is also independent
of the mixture. This is due to the fact that the maxi-
mum width is imposed by the width of the hemisphere in
which beads are initially placed [5]. If the slope of the de-

5.2 Interface eﬀects between two superposed layers of
beads
The interface eﬀects take into account:

During the ﬂow, there are two superposed layers, the layer
of large beads is above the layer of small beads. Due to
the equilibrium between the driving forces and the basal
friction, each layer of beads has his own velocity. The layer
of large beads scrapes on the layer of small beads and
consequently that slows down the layer of large beads and
speeds up the layer of small beads. We call this interaction

C. Goujon et al.: Bidisperse granular avalanches on inclined planes: A rich variety of behaviors
213

the “dragging” of the layer of small beads by the large
ones.
5.2.1 Dragging of the lower layer by the upper one

The interface eﬀect between the small and the large beads
layers takes into account an interface roughness which im-
plies the diameter dl compared to the diameter of small
beads ds, and the compactness of the upper part of the
layer of the small beads and of the lower part of the
layer of large beads. We could consider the layer of small
beads as a “moving rough plane”. But it is not possible to
use directly the study of interaction of beads on a rough
plane [5], because these interactions do not take place on
glued beads which cannot move, but on moveable small
beads. We suppose that if the big ones push the others,
this eﬀect is a function of the mass ratio of the two types
of beads. The parameters of this interface eﬀect, are the
ratio of the diameters dl/ds and the compactness of each
layer of beads. If the thickness of the ﬂow is large, we con-
sider that the compactness of the upper part of the layer of
small beads is equal to the random compactness of a ﬂow
and is independent of the size of the beads. In this case, the
dragging eﬀect varies mainly with the diameter ratio. If
the thickness of the small beads layer is thin, its compact-
ness can be modiﬁed by the interaction of the small beads
with the rough plane. For small bead diameters greater
than dc, the compactness is probably smaller than a ran-
dom compactness. This is due to the fact that the pattern
of the rough plane is somehow transmitted through the
thin layer of small beads. For diameters of small beads re-
ally smaller than dc, the compactness of the layer of small
beads is probably the same as in the case of a thick ﬂow
and equal to a random compactness. Consequently, the
interaction between the small beads and the rough plane
may have an inﬂuence on the large beads layer in the case
of thin ﬂows.
The dragging of the small beads can be quantiﬁed by
interesting to the thickness of the small beads deposit.
Figures 14(b), 20(b), 21(b) show that the thickness of the
deposit in the bidisperse case is smaller than the thickness
obtained for monodisperse ﬂow composed of small beads.
We have previously seen in Section 2, that the thickness of
the deposit hstop is a characteristic of the rheology of the
ﬂow and should only depend on θ. We conclude that the
dragging of the small beads by the large ones may lead to
a modiﬁcation of the velocity proﬁle in the layer of small
beads. The mean velocity of the small beads is larger than
in the monodisperse case, and this increase of the velocity
leads to a decrease of the thickness hstop of the layer of
small beads deposit.
5.2.2 Trapping of beads on the deposit

For some experimental conditions, the thickness of small
beads deposit is not measurable because some large beads
stay stable on the deposit of small beads. We call this

eﬀect the “trapping” of large beads on the layer of small
beads.
The increase of the thickness observed in Figures 14, 15
and 23 is a consequence of the trapping of large beads
on the layer of small beads. We can determine, by image
analysis, the total contour of the deposit as well as the
contour of the deposit of the small beads. The area of the
large beads trapped on the deposit of small beads can be
determined and thus the area ratio deﬁned by the area of
large beads trapped on the deposit of small beads divided
by the area of the deposit of small beads. We ﬁnd that
the trapping occurs for values of the area ratios between
0.55 and 0.81. In the case of non-trapping (almost no
large beads on the deposit), the area ratio is lower than
0.01. We set arbitrarily the limit trapping/not trapping
at 0.1. Table 4 presents the diﬀerent conﬁgurations, for
which the trapping of large beads occurs or does not
occur. The trapping of the large beads on the layer of
small beads occurs for diameter ratios smaller than 1.68
(in the case of an angle of inclination equal to 25◦and for
a percentage of large beads equal to 50%). The value of
the diameter ratio corresponding to this limit may vary
with both the angle of inclination and the percentage of
large beads. We could expect that the limit increases at
small angles and experiments made at 19◦do not give
any additional information on the limit. The value of
the limit is not very sensitive to the percentage of large
beads %l as we did not observe any strong change in the
presence or absence of large beads on the deposit.
Consequently the thickness of the deposit may be
larger than the thickness of the deposit left by a mono-
disperse ﬂow of small beads.

We have identiﬁed eﬀects governing the bidisperse granu-
lar ﬂows on inclined planes: outline and interface eﬀects.

We have previously seen that the conﬁning leads to a rapid
decrease of the width and consequently to an increase of
the length. The interface eﬀects can lead to i) a decrease
of the thickness of the deposit, due to the dragging of the
small beads by the large beads or to ii) an increase of the
total thickness of the deposit due to the trapping of large
beads on the layer of small beads (even if the deposit thick-
ness of small beads probably decreases at the same time).
However, for all the conﬁgurations, these eﬀects occur
simultaneously. This implies a diﬃcult interpretation of
our results and a study of each separate eﬀect very del-
icate. But we can qualitatively interpret our results by
using these eﬀects and their combination.

For the group-B experiments, for which ds < dc and
µ2,s > µ2,l (presented in Sect. 4.2.2), we observe an in-
crease of the length L of the deposit compared to the
length given by equation (1) (Figs. 20 and 21). This in-
crease of the length can be linked to the decrease of the
thickness of the deposit of small beads compared to the
monodisperse case. Moreover, for these experiments, there
is some increase of the width with respect to the mono-
disperse case (the deposit is widened). The impact of the
variation of the thickness on the length is greater than
those of the variation of the width. It appears that in
this case, there is no narrowing of the ﬂow: only inter-
face eﬀects play a role. For the diameter ratios we study
(dl/ds > 3.4) there is no trapping in agreement with other
observations (Tab. 4).
The behavior of these bidisperse ﬂows is only governed
by the dragging eﬀect, which leads to a decrease of the
thickness of the small beads deposit and consequently to
an increase of the length of the deposit. The study of this
conﬁguration will be the subject of a future paper.

For the group-C experiments, for which ds > dc (presented
in Sect. 4.2.3), the basal friction of large beads is smaller
than the basal friction of small beads. The length of the
deposit is smaller than the length given by relation (1)
and larger than the length given by relation (2) (Fig. 23).
In this case, the deposit is not narrowed, so we suppose
that only interface eﬀects happen: dragging of the small
beads by the large beads and trapping of the large beads
on the deposit of small beads.
The trapping of large beads on the layer of small beads
prevent the formation of a deposit of large beads ahead the
deposit of small beads, which could have been very long
(due to the small thickness of a deposit of a monodisperse
granular ﬂow of large beads). Consequently, if there is only
trapping, the length of the deposit would decrease with
the percentage of large beads (reference state (2)). The
dragging of the small beads by the large beads leads to
a decrease of the thickness of the layer of small beads.

Consequently, if there is only dragging, the length of the
deposit would increase with the percentage of large beads.
In Figure 23, for percentages of large beads smaller
than 20%, the length of the deposit decreases, this is linked
to an increase of the thickness. Moreover, these experi-
mental results are very close to the reference length given
by equation (2). That means that all the large beads are
trapped on the deposit of small beads and the dragging is
negligible.
For percentages of large beads larger than 20%, the
length of the deposit increases, this is linked to the de-
crease of the thickness: dragging appears. The decrease
of the thickness under hstop,mono,s for %l > 50 is a clear
evidence of the dragging of the small beads.
Dragging and trapping, occur for all the percentages,
but results show that the trapping dominates the ﬂow for
the small percentages of large beads, and the dragging
rather dominates the ﬂow for larger values of the percent-
age.
5.3.3 Dragging, conﬁning with or without trapping

For the group-A experiments, for which ds < dc and µ2,s <
µ2,l (presented in Sect. 4.2.1), we observe an increase of
the length of the deposit compared to the length given by
equation (1); moreover, in this case the ﬂow is narrowed.

(Figs. 14, 15), the thickness of the deposit is larger
than the thickness of the deposit of the monodisperse
case. This can be explained by the trapping of the
large beads on the layer of small beads. Moreover, the
length of the deposit decreases with the percentage of
small beads and it is close to the law obtained by rela-
tion (1). The trapping eﬀect on L almost balances the
dragging and the conﬁning eﬀects.
– For larger size ratios (Fig. 14), there is no trapping and
there is a decrease of the thickness of the layer of small
beads in the deposit compared to the monodisperse
case. In this case, conﬁning and dragging occur simul-
taneously and act on the length in the same way.

For all the conﬁgurations, the behavior of bidisperse ﬂows
are governing by outline and interface eﬀects. Due to the
fact that these eﬀects occur simultaneously, it is diﬃcult
to study each of these eﬀects. Nevertheless, we are able
to identify the impact of each eﬀect for the diﬀerent con-
ﬁgurations. For understanding all these eﬀects, it will be
important to deﬁne other ﬂow or beads conﬁgurations for
which these eﬀects occur separately.

In this study, we identify the eﬀects governing the bidis-
perse granular ﬂows on inclined rough planes. These ﬂows
are inhomogeneous because of the phenomenon of segrega-
tion. The ﬁrst consequence of the segregation is to organize
the ﬂow in two superposed layers of beads ﬂowing on each
other. Due to the velocity ﬁeld, this vertical organization

C. Goujon et al.: Bidisperse granular avalanches on inclined planes: A rich variety of behaviors
215

leads to spatial, lateral and longitudinal heterogeneities.
For a mixture of small and large beads, the large beads are
at the surface of the ﬂow, on the sides and at the front,
the small beads are at the base of the ﬂow. This pecu-
liar geometry leads to consider diﬀerent eﬀects having an
inﬂuence on the general dynamics of the ﬂow:

– an eﬀect due to the presence of large beads on the
outline of the ﬂow (front and sides of the ﬂow),
– an interaction between the two superposed layers,
– a modiﬁcation of the basal roughness depending on the
size of beads which is in contact with the rough plane.

By comparing the basal frictions of each class of beads
on an inclined rough plane, we can study and understand
the limit of the outline eﬀect. If the basal friction of large
beads is smaller than the basal friction of small beads, no
forces are acting on the outline of the ﬂow. By judiciously
choosing the diameter of each class of beads of the bidis-
perse mixture, this outline eﬀect can be suppressed. If the
basal friction of the large beads is larger than the basal
friction of the small beads, the bidisperse ﬂow is narrowed
because of the large basal friction of the large beads acting
on the outline of the ﬂow. Diﬀerent phenomena, depending
on the percentage of large beads, appear: rapid stop of the
ﬂow and decrease of the width and the length of the de-
posit (for large percentage of large beads) or formation of
a ﬁnger and increase of the length (for intermediate value
of the percentage of large beads). The conﬁning is one
cause of the increase of the length of bidisperse deposits.
These ﬂows are also governed by the interface eﬀects,
that are the interaction between the layers of beads and
the interaction of the small beads with the rough plane.
Interactions between layers of beads are of two types: the
trapping of large beads on the deposit of small beads and
the dragging ahead of the layer of small beads by the layer
of large beads. By reducing the trapping of the large beads
on the deposit of small beads, the thickness of the small-
beads deposit is measurable and decreases due to the drag-
ging of the small beads by the large beads. The dragging is
also one cause of the increase of the length of propagation
of the ﬂow.
This work gives a frame to the study of bidisperse ﬂows
on inclined rough planes by pointing out the mechanisms
involved. But for all the bidisperse ﬂows, these diﬀerent
eﬀects occur simultaneously, which implies diﬃculties to
separately study and quantify each of these eﬀects. For
this, one must determine the adequate parameter values
for which it might be possible to emphasize or separate
each mechanism and study them separately.
